-This anime has a very balanced, simple, warm and crystalline art.The art is like a mirror,an accompaniment  for the beautiful songs,played by the symphonic  orchestra.The art gives peaceful feelings,mysterious and wonderful feelings.The decors are subtile and nuanced. The characters's design is realistic, and not excessive (as in normal shoujo animes).The characters are beautiful but without to be seen as "bishoujos or bishounes".They also have very expressive facial expressions,and mimics.The bodys  echilibrate beautiful with the atmospher,creating beautiful symmetry.


                                                                       Score:10


The sound:

-Nodame Cantabile, with sections of music by Rachmaninov, Liszt, Brahms, Gershwin, Beethoven, and Chopin that are performed by the characters in the series. The performers included the Vienna Philharmonic, London Symphony Orchestra, and Berlin Philharmonic. The anime include works by Beethoven, Rachmaninov, Gershwin, Liszt, Mozart, Debussy, Ravel, and Richard Strauss that are performed by characters.

The seiyū Ayako Kawasumi,also plays piano in the real life.I heard some of the pieces of the composers like Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Ludwig Von Beethoven, Franz Schubert, Antonio Vivaldi, Johann Sebastian Bach,but I enjoyed to hear them more in the anime as OST-s than in real life,they had something "fresh" about them,more sweet and tangible, a real  delightfullness for someone's ears.I felt  like I was thrown in alternative space,with a heavenly music.


                                                                       Score:10


Characters:

-The main characters and the interaction between them is a joy for the watcher.The anime is a beautiful,subtile contrast between humor,amusement and drama .

Even if Shinichi Chiaki is sometime bossy and cinic,he has a good sense of music (and people).He is a also a good cook and has a funny personality.He can encourages people with talent and helps them to achieve their goals.He is also perfectionist and more critical of himself than with others.

Megumi Noda is a very complex character,she hides herself in her dream world and childish fantasizes,runs away from everything she doesn't like and disagree with.She is a glutton when it comes to food and Chiaki.She is stubborn and lazy.In her childhood she had problems with her proffesor 's tough and exigent  way of teaching.

But her optimism and courage is remarkable. Tomoko Ninomiya did a very good job creating this characters.


                                                                       Score:10


Enjoyment:

-This anime is a must see,a master piece which is one of the greatest animes made in 2007.


                                                                       Score:10


Overall: Score: 10.


This was my first review ever made,I quite enjoyed making it ^^ .

These days, I often feel that slice of life is a very much misunderstood genre. Back in the days of "NieA Under 7" and "Beck", it seemed to be a little talked about subgenre of "drama". But a few years ago, for reasons unknown to me, it suddenly exploded into mainstream popularity to the extent that it's now totally eclipsing its parent genre, with anything and everything being (often wrongly) labelled as "slice of life". The small subgenre of genuine slice of life anime however, has always been, in my experience, one of the most consistent genres. They are the kind of anime that dealswith the mundane, anime that are often contemplative reflections of various, often under-appreciated aspects of daily life.


...and then there's "Nodame Cantabile" (and its sequels), a slice of life set in a classical music conservatory. "Nodame Cantabile" is to slice of life anime what the great J.S.Bach is to Baroque music. Just as Bach took the various aspect of Baroque music and brought them to their ultimate form, "Nodame Cantabile" takes the various aspects of slice of life and combines them into into a show that's raises the bar for the genre. It's funny and entertaining without resorting to the forced humour of "Honey and Clover", it's passionate about its subject matter without the exclusiveness of "Genshiken", and it's thought provoking and inspiring without the heavy-handedness of "Planetes". And as someone who's learning piano, it's a series that's really helped fuel my interest not only in piano, but classical music in general (so I might be a tad biased :D [/disclaimer]).


[ Warning: I kind of got a bit carried away while writing this and ended up with a rather in depth character analysis section. So be warned that this review contains spoilers regarding the direction of the character development ]


"Nodame Cantabile" is not just for classical music enthusiasts (I certainly wasn't one... at least not when I started this anime), there's plenty of other things such as the fabulous character interactions that makes it an awesome watch for the general audience. The storyline isn't completely sensible, but while its occasional use of comedy to progress the story marks it out as one of the more quirky and perhaps less realistic slice of life series, there is no doubt that the values conveyed and the way with which it goes about conveying them are definitive slice of life stuff. It contains plenty of food for thought, as themes such as self improvement and questions concerning ambitions and talent are cleverly woven into the very fabric of the story.


Take for example Chiaki, one of the two protagonists of the series. It's obvious from the start of the show that he's a hugely talented musician and can play the violin incredibly well despite being a piano major. Of course, people often has this misconception that things must be come easily to people like him, that these kinds of people hardly need to practice etc, and this is exactly what Mine (a violin student) thought when he's just getting to know Chiaki. But it turns out Chiaki is good on the violin because he'd put in a sickening amount of practice on it prior to entering the academy, where he chose to learn piano precisely because he wasn't as skilled at it. And this is astounding if you think about it, because it completely goes against people's natural instincts, which is pick their strongest subject to study. The fact that Chiaki is willing to take his weakness head on to turn it into his strength is an indication of his incredible drive and commitment. And eventually, Mine begins to appreciate that the secret behind Chiaki's success is not just talent, noting that: "He is amazing, but he's backed up by his hard work." In contrast, the other protagonist Nodame, who is also very talented, is lounging around at the bottom of the class with the stragglers, and this really effectively hammers home the message that there's simply no substitute for honest hard work.


Chiaki may work incredibly hard, and may possess incredible musical talent, but he soon finds that sometimes this still isn't enough. His ultimate goal is to become a conductor, and his interactions with various orchestras make up a significant part of the series, throwing up some extremely interesting character interaction and development. The main point of interest here is how Chiaki get to grips with this new role. Despite being fully prepared, and despite being so talented to the extent that he can hear the fault of every instrument in the orchestra (which is an incredible feat itself), he still struggled initially to keep things under control and get them to produce the sound he's looking for. Gradually, he learns that conducting is not just about the music and the technical stuff, the human factor is also very important - getting everyone to gel and striking a balance between being critical of the faults in the performances and keeping the players' morale up all combine to make the task a mammoth one. I know next to nothing about conducting (other than the fact that it's supposed to be ridiculously hard), but I find the scenarios in "Nodame Cantabile" to be extremely believable. If you ever thought conducting should be easy with some guy just waving a baton around, this would almost certainly change your opinion.


Though undoubtedly a romantic comedy, "Nodame Cantabile" is relatively light in this aspect, and the romance that is contained in the show has everything to do with music. It's because of her music that Nodame is first able to catch the attention of Chiaki. However it's also because of the music that's there's a gulf separating them. Chiaki's lofty goals means that he's unwilling be anchored by the lack of ambition shown by Nodame, for whom music is initially nothing more than just a fun thing to do. The series' romance revolves around this idea that unless Nodame start taking her music more seriously, Chiaki would soon be heading to a place she can't follow. And though Chiaki's efforts to drag her upwards does have some effect, it would take a lot more than a small change in attitude for them to not drift apart at some point in the future.


The character development is not limited to the romance. Chiaki's constant strive for excellence inspires not only Nodame, but also stragglers like Mine to take a more serious, disciplined approach to learning music, and consequently they are gradually able to understand and appreciate better the intentions of the composer in the pieces they play. But what's perhaps more remarkable is that influences are mutual - Chiaki is already incredibly good at the start of the series, but there's still plenty of things for him to learn about music from the straggler students. In particular, his contact with Nodame's wild, untamed talents enables him to take a more complete view of music - it helps him to look beyond his strict, by-the-score methods and realise the value of individuality of musical expression. This ties in with the development that his general personality undergoes: because of his interactions with Nodame and with his first orchestra etc, we see him gradually changing from the cold, aloof perfectionist at the start to a much more warm and understanding person by the end.


I don't think it can be denied that "Nodame Cantabile" is an anime that radiates an infectious enthusiasm for classical music, so it's only fitting that I talk a bit (read: extensively) about the music in the series. It should come as no surprise that classical music is omnipresent within the series. The music performed by the students of the conservatory are obviously all from this genre, but the background instrumentals also contain (often tongue-in-cheek) arrangements of famous pieces such as Beethoven's "Moonlight Sonata" and Tchaikovski's "Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy". There are also some nice BGM's that I don't recognise which may be classical music that I'm not familiar with. And though the OP's and ED's aren't classical pieces, there are some connections to classical music even there: the lyrics of the wildly catchy opening theme "Allegro Cantabile" features heavy usage of terms from classical music (as you can see from its title); the second ending theme, plain though it may be, also begins with a really nice violin/piano intro that makes for a blissfully "fade in" music as each episode comes to an end. (The first ending theme is pretty forgettable, but hey - you can't have everything :P) The music that are performed by the students in the series deserve special mention, because a phenomenal effort has been made to tailor most if not all the performances to suit the context in which the performance took place. [Note: If you want to know more about this, I've dedicated a whole section to analysing this aspect. I've put it at the end of the review so as to not bore the readers who aren't interested in this stuff.]


Of course, all of this leads to a potential problem - though it's easy to like "Nodame Cantabile" even if you're not into classical music, it's a completely different kettle of fish if you hate classical music, especially given that there are long periods, especially towards the end of the series, where you just get a piece of music being performed and not much else happening. This may also bore a not-so-patient viewer who's not that into the music being performed, though it's not something you can really fault the anime for - it's obviously very passionate about classical music after all, and so it's kind of expected that it would invest some time into showing the performances. For those who don't have a knee jerk negative reaction to classical music, it's easy to be caught up in the anime's passion. In particular, I find the characters' thoughts on a piece of music when it's being performed to be an integral part of enjoying the music of "Nodame Cantabile". The "flower garden" of Beethoven's "Spring", the very graceful and "pink" Mozart Oboe Concerto, and the piano play of the Rachmaninoff piano concerto that "illuminates like the morning light in a bottomless ravine"... the well written commentry often combine with the music to form an immersive, spine-tingling atmosphere that effortlessly drew me in, especially during the performances. Often, the audience reactions may be a little exaggerated, but by that point I'd be so taken in by the atmosphere that the exaggerated reactions only added further to the mood. "Nodame Cantabile" can also be quite enlightening with regards to the music being played, often providing insight and background information about the music that really encriched the experience - it's a show that obviously knows its stuff. 


Anyway, I feel like I've gushed for long enough already. If you love drama, if you love music, or if you want to be inspired, then "Nodame Cantabile" has my highest recommendation.


***


For those who are interested, here's some extra information on the music used in Nodame Cantabile that I picked up. Before I begin, I should give a little background about myself (just so you know how large a grain of salt to take with my opinions on this :P) The first time I watched this series was soon after I started (re-)learning piano at the ripe old age of 24 (I did learn for a couple of years starting when I was about 4 or 5, but had completely forgotten everything by the time I started again). On my first watch, I often wondered whether how closely the music performed in the series matched the commentary made on it. Is the music really performed badly when characters say it sucks, and is it honestly good when they say it's good? It all sounded fine to me! Coming back to this series over two years later with more piano practice under my belt and having listened to many of the pieces found in the show, I now have a better idea about the music performed. So basically my level of expertise isn't very high - I can probably pick up more than a casual listener, but anyone who's studied a bit of classical music would probably know a lot more than I.


In fact, for pieces that gets played properly in "Nodame Cantabile", I STILL can't really tell exactly how good they are, because the quality is far enough above the average homemade youtube video performance by random people with usernames along the lines of z0MG1337_pIaNisT that I'm not really in a position to judge. However, for pieces I'm sufficiently familiar with, I can at least verify that when a character (usually Chiaki) points out that there is a mistake in the performance, then there definitely is a corresponding mistake in the music that is used for that scene. More impressively, one of the main characters Nodame is supposed to be a very talented but eccentric (not always in a good way) pianist, and on my second viewing I was actually able to hear some of the eccentricity in her playing. In particular, her playing of the 2nd movement of Beethoven's famous "Pathetique Sonata" is very distinctive. The piece is supposed to be a sombre, gloomy one, but Nodame plays the left hand part in an almost stoccato like way, and the whole piece is given a bouncing, frolicking interpretation that is a perfect reflection of her own personality.


Now, as unbelievable as all this already is, I'd assumed that the same effort is not applied to the orchestral performances, since getting a proper orchestra to perform and tailor their mistakes to the anime would be far more effort than tailoring solo/duet pieces. Also, I could not really tell any difference between the repeated performances of these pieces during the various orchestra rehearsal sessions in the anime. Upon listening to the sound track of the show though, I was shocked to discover that I'd completely underestimated "Nodame Cantabile". For example, there're several tracks dedicated to a single section of an orchestral piece, and just listening to the music by itself allowed me to focus and detect some messiness in the performances, but here's the surprising thing - these tracks are all subtly different! They must have been used for the different rehearsal sessions I was referring to! This really is phenomenal, jaw dropping attention to detail. Seems like they've pulled out all the stops when making "Nodame Cantabile"... and what a splendid piece of work it turned out to be.

Perhaps one of the most underrated anime you'll come across.
Being a music anime, it's easy to understand why it wouldn't interest many when it comes to plotline. It was really by chance that I stumbled on this gem.
Probably the first thing you'll notice about this show is it's unique animation and art. While at first it might not appeal to the eyes, the designs really grow on you and fit the show very well.
When it comes to the characters, you can only say that they were on point. The main's, Nodame and Chiaki, enjoy really fun-filled chemistry while the supporting cast is really well done.
Animportant part of the show, that people can really appreciate, the level to which they focus on music in this anime. It doesn't play a side role like it does in anime such as Shigatsu ( which honestly shouldn't be classified music but rather drama). 



If you're thinking about watching a comedy with a slice of romance that focuses on music there isn't anything out there that's better than this anime.

For an artist-musician Nodame Cantabile is perfetto, emozionante, allegro, divertente, concreto ...I can really feel the emotions, the characters are going through... They give me the ispiration  to go on and be better...I couldn't stop watching untill the end "e che FINALE"...The graphic was unique ... the different tecnics went well toghether ... the idea to use the computer to simulate the movements of the musician and to recreate the instruments perfecly... moments captured with potraits...and the music was really the heart of Nodame Cantabile ... GUARDATELO O PERDERETE UN OPPORTUNITA INCREDIBILE!!! VIVA NODAME CANTABILE!!!

Before watching Your Lie In April, I didn't ever have any interest in anime where the focal point was music. So, with how much I enjoyed that anime, I decided to give Nodame Cantabile a try. From the very first episode, I knew I was going to enjoy it.
Story: As the story mostly revolves around Chiaki's amazing talent as a pianist, violinist, and ultimately his goal of becoming a conductor, I think it was really great to watch his development into the man he wants to become. Nodame, the woman with a wild style of playing the piano is the only person who seems capableof matching Chiaki, in her own way. The development of these two and the supporting characters in this story is very enjoyable.


Art: The art is pretty good. There's nothing terrible about it, and the attention to detail on all of the instruments is pretty damn impressive. The character art is funny, and decent as well.


Sound: It's an anime about music, so as expected, the sound is outstanding. All of the OST for the anime is some version of classical music, and then all of the music pieces in competitions etc are a beauty to listen to. I seriously want to go to Orchestra one day now.


Character: Chiaki and Nodame are both great characters with their own aspirations, fears, and backstories. Additionally, there are so many supporting characters with interesting personalities and skills in music that it's pretty difficult to ever find time to grow bored with this series. I'm hoping to these characters return in Nodame Cantabile: Paris-hen.


Enjoyment: I laughed a lot. Really enjoyed all of the live music presentations, and actually even found myself tearing up listening to how intense some of the music was as well. Definitely, DEFINITELY need to visit an orchestra someday.


Overall: A solid 8 for sure. Really good anime series, worth watching for sure.

Lesson 1: Anime
Total Episodes; 23+1 Summer special. A new (11 episode) season to come October 9th, 2008. (Airing at the moment.)
Genres; Classical Music, Comedy, Slice of life, Romance
Similar animes with music as a theme are for example 'BECK: Monogolian Chop Squad' and 'Piano no Mori'.
Opening/Ending;
OP- Suemitsu & The Suemith - Allegro Cantabile
An exciting and mood bringing opening. It starts with the main characters and later shows the scene's with objects or instruments that are involved in the series. It's a colourful and joyful opening song.
ED 1- Crystal Kay - Konna ni Chikaku de...
With the same art as in the opening it has an ordinary endingwith Chiaki the main character and a weird mongoose walking the piano keys.\n
ED 2- Suemitsu & The Suemith – Sagittarius\n
Again, the same art that is colourful and plain. It shows some piano's twirling round with the main characters later on them.\n\n
Lesson 2: Manga\n
Authors; Ninomiya, Tomoko (Story & Art)\n
Chapters; 124 – ongoing\n
Published; July 10th 2001 to … (Hiatus?! Mangaka had a baby! Cheers!)\n
Serialization; Kiss\n\n
Lesson 3: Plot - 9.5/10\n
The son of a famous pianist, Chiaki Shinichi is a 3rd year piano student at the Japanese Momogaoka Music Academy and has a dream to become a conductor. He has a passion for classical music, plays the violin and piano wonderfully and can hear the differences between a good or bad musician. One day he meets someone he actually has never seen before. Her name is Noda 'Nodame' Megumi, who is a 2nd year piano student at the same school. He is disgusted by her sloppiness and attitude but fascinated by her playing. Before he even knew it, he is drug into her rhythm. As the story continues, he meets up with more 'weirdo' students and his father's rival, and perverted famous conductor, Stresemann.\n\n
Lesson 4: Characterization - 9/10\n
The characters are well thought out and have their own traits. Nodame is a special case and is characterized by her being annoying towards some people, very sloppy and shouting all kinds of phrases like 'gyabo' or 'mukya'. Every character within the series experiences growth, not only in skill, but in character as well. Throughout the series you get enough air time per character to know how they respond to certain events and story development. Expressing emotions and thoughts are shared with the viewer and give a good impression or explanation about the character. Every character is unique in it's own way and has an important role in the series.\n\n
Lesson 5: Anime animation & Music - 8.5/10\n
The animation is plain and simple, not that different from most anime series out there. Scenery, character drawings and animations are very good. Character interaction is greatly done and sometimes gives a humorous effect. The orchestra's playing is well put together, but is lacking mostly, which reduces the enjoyment of that moment or scene where it was the most important. (Definitely improved in Nodame Cantabile: Paris-hen!) The selling point of the series is classical music. If you like classical music you might enjoy the series, but keep in mind that there are other parts of the series that get attention. The music selection is not just limited to famous piano composers but also contains other instrument's composers. It is really thought out and researched. One can actually learn some parts of World music history. Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Beethoven, Chopin, Schubert, Liszt, Stravinsky and Brahms are some of the few composers that are talked about throughout the series.\n\n
Lesson 6: Manga art - 8/10\n
The art is clean and understandable, not messy nor over exaggerated. It is mostly focused on the characters interaction between one another, barely any extra art. Buildings, orchestra's and other scenery are well drawn and has a realistic, impressive look. Actions or movements are well shown and give the reader a good idea of what is going on without giving the impression that it is just to fill gaps. The structure and lay out of the manga is flexible and simple to understand. Text bubbles, music notes and other sound-related items are well placed over the series, being correctly used. The cover pages are varied with different characters and multiple instruments. If you see the oldest and newest chapter, you will notice slight to no difference in the drawings.\n\n
Lesson 7: Personal review - 9.5/10\n
Nodame Cantabile has become one of my favourite series. I strongly recommend it to anyone, even if you dislike the genre slice of life or classical music. The whole theme gives it's own feeling and is pretty unique amongst animes and mangas. The further you get in the series and get to know the characters, the more you wish there was more episodes.\n\n
Last Lesson: Overall - 9/10

I thought the overall story was very good, but in the first season I thought the animators were kind of lazy. There were so many static scenes that were only kept moving by the sound. I also thought some shots were reused a lot. Although giving life to classical music could be really hard in an anime that centers on music, I still thought those kinds of scenes bring down an otherwise good anime. But looking at it the other way around, the first season is a good base/set-up for the next two seasons. It showed how good the musicality of the characters are, howimportant music is to them, and maybe not a lot but good enough background checks.  Overall, the anime was fun and consistent. The next two seasons were a whole lot better though, especially the finale. 


The anime (all 3 seasons) was also especially interesting for me because it was the first shoujo/josei anime I’ve noticed (since I’m only noticing these things recently) that it was the male protagonist that narrates the story, hence we can look into his thoughts. There were no annoying musings of the heroine. The heroine was strong and weird. Although she’s somehow completely dependent on the male protagonist, she’s also independent – really weird. Those stuff adds to the consistency points of the story because it was really impossible to read the heroine’s mind – that is if there was even something that goes around her head. 


There were also more comedy than romance, but when there is romance, it can really tug your heartstrings. And by telling it from the male point of view who is kind of a tsundere and who doesn’t say much, it’s seriously more effective.

A story of love and life through the music of Piano. Trust me not to under estimate this anime because it will bring life into classical music in a modern world especially that it has an anime setting.
Nodame Cantabile shows the everyday life of Chiaki and Nodame together as they go through their hardships in becoming better musicians while falling in love for each other.
A highly recommended anime for classical music lovers and romance fans.

Oh my gosh! I really can't believe how much I've enjoyed this. I've just watched the last episode and can't wait to watch the specials and anything associated! It took me back to when i was in the orchestra and rekindled my passion for my clarinet! This anime is heart warming,the characters are funny and lovable. The animation style is very soft and detailed. There's a constant background of harmony and peace regardless of what's going on.I'm sure the classical music has a lot to do with that.Just like the soft colour tones and animation style, there are subtle hints of a deeper story.This seasonhas made me want to know more about Nodame and Chiaki characters.The main thing about this anime is that is fun and extremely addictive, after the first few episodes. If You like classical music, witty humour, diverse characters with huge egos all wrapped up in everyday life at a japanese music university,then this is for you.

Nodame Cantabile is about a talented male musician who aspires to be a conductor and how his life change when he met a wired female pianist who has unnaturally good piano skills.
The story was different from your usual music anime as it was more to the classical side. I think that the story is realistic to some extent and it gives a good insight into the music industry.On another note, the romance is not so evident, it does have some but not as much as your high school anime or lovestory. The focus is more on the lives of the two of them and howthey progress in the music industry. But it is still quite captivating thanks to the character development.


The art was ok,not the best i've seen but still reasonable,since i'm not so big on the artwork of anime i don't really mind so much.


The music was excellent. Not just the opening and ending songs but the pieces played in the anime are very melodious and entrancing.SO if you like classical music this is a must watch for you. Plus they don't play the same pieces all the time like in other music anime, it is usually different for each episode.


The characters are portrayed extremely well and the flash backs bring out the drama and sentiment in the show, and express the fact that hardship id part of the road to glory and perfection. The character development in this story of both male and female leads is extraordinary and evident. but the lack of focus on the supporting characters makes it a little less realistic and a bit bias,but i guess it was necessary for the character development.


The anime had a good deal of comic relief and this made it quite enjoyable, i especially love nodame and her extremely fast speed at playing the piano.The synergy that is displayed between the two character also makes it quite entertaining.


SO if you love classical music or an anime where the characters go through drastic changes with some romance then this anime is for you, but dont keep you hopes high on the romance, but be sure that there is a reasonable amount of drama.

I normally try to keep my reviews formal, but what the heck! GYABO! This anime is just too good to try and be formal with. I mean seriously, just the enjoyment itself is really quite thrilling. But, before I get to the good stuff I'll start to with the weak parts of the anime so I could end with a good note. 
I gotta say, the only thing that I didn't like about the anime are the characters. I would say that this anime did a much better job at portraying that genre of "slice of life" better than a lot of the anime I'veseen (I've seen a lot, but I haven't reviewed all, yet). But, sometimes it gets carried away. I mean I get that it's anime, but I would have want it to be a little bit more settled, especially when it came down to the part where Nodame high kicks Chiaki. PRICELESS! But she didn't need that big jump because to be honest I jump high, but you gotta be a wickedly high jumper to do that. Though, this DOES NOT affect my thoughts on Nodame, or any of the other characters! Seriously, this anime is just so good!


Now as for the awesomeness of this anime, I can't even begin to tell you how great this anime is. But, here are just a few things I really enjoyed about it. First of all, like I said, the genre part of "slice of life" was on the spot. You can feel like it might just happen to anyone, except the part if you're going be like Chiaki... Also Nodame-chan's POV is very mysterious and can be fun to play along because it feels like she's just like any hormonal girl who's in a one-sided love. 


Over all a solid 9, still looking for that 10... 


Until then, this is Usa-chan man (BunnyMafia) waving good-bye.

Nodame Cantabile is a music anime, centered around music prodigy Chiaki Shinichi and his neighbor, the titular Nodame, Noda Megumi. It spans several years' worth of their lives, starting from mid-university until after graduation and the formation of their plans for adult life.
It explores the world of classical music institutions and the hubbub surrounding them, and sheds light into how such talented people might find gainful employment, all while developing and interacting characters without too much unnecessary drama.
It's not a high-school anime by any means. The characters are not high-school kids, and it shows. They are young adults, with their thoughts full of the futureand their plans for it, but still not having lost the drive and luster of youth.


Music anime are easy to get behind. Unlike other forms of art being used as mediums for such stories, music is probably the easiest to present on an anime series, and it often works to draw people in. Classical music might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I guarantee that even for those people, Nodame Cantabile will be enjoyable, as the series balances the music sections with plot, character advancement and interaction and comedy rather well.


Honestly, the series hits several of my personal things I enjoy watching. Chiaki, arguably the protagonist, is a capable young man, prodigious but not hilariously, stereotypical ingenius and perfect at everything like you often see on manga/anime. He has his own faults and mistakes that he has to strive to correct, and he does so in a realistic manner and with the help of people around him. He's capable, reasonable, opinionated and flawed. Just my kind of character.


Nodame, conversely, is none of those things. Well, except flawed. She balances precariously on the scale of ridiculouslness, with arguably success. She's eccentric; unclean, talented at piano but unorthodox in her way of learning and playing. Still, it works for the story. Nodame and her character play a major role in the story, as much as Chiaki, but her randomness is never pushed into our face as if it's character trait worth admiring, which I respect. Her character arc is arguably more defined than Chiaki's, who knew what he wanted and how to get it. Nodame is troubled, and has to work with some phobias, indecision and bad habits. It all plays out beautifully in the 23 episodes of the series.


The music, is, as expected, superb. Though a person more educated in classical music would probably pick out a lot more of the subtle differences in the various scenes, there is enough commentary by the characters that we get a pretty good idea of what's going on, and honestly it's just a joy to listen to most of the time.


The secondary cast is not weak, but not particularly strong either. We get to follow several somewhat interesting characters and see their progression in the world of music over time, and we are introduced to some interesting families and people, but in the end the secondary cast fails to draw interest without the presence of either of the lead characters in the scene.


The animation is okay. Good, without being particularly groundbreaking. One of my main gripes with the series is that Chiaki is a conductor, but we never actually see him DO any conducting. Just one or two frames with him in a pose and the assumption that he is conducting really, really hard. Conversely, the piano and other instrumental parts are animated a lot better, with details as regarding finger movements, etc.


It's a good anime with a coherent and well-paced plot, decently animated, with (mostly) mature characters, striving to bring their dreams to fruition against various issues and problems. A touch of drama here and there, an abundance of humor and, most importantly, lots and lots of good music.


9/10

Im coming back to this after watching it for a second time because it's just SO GOOD (also at least for me it's been super rewatchable). 
If you voted anything besides a 10 for the music, you dont deserve to live-the orchestra and piano parts are fantastic, and having the music play a critical role in influencing/reflecting the lives of the characters was an amazing and really smart directorial idea.
It was also super good at refreshing an interest in classical music and all of its beautiful ridiculous nuances.
Not to mention on TOP of all that the characters are amazing and are well rounded and developedby the end of the series. If you dont love them as much as the music pls kys <3

When I first began this anime and have gone through a couple of reviews, my expectations were high and my reality was low. I began this anime and thought of it very differently and expected it to be annoying, however it turned out to be even better than I expected. However at the time I was turning down many animes and decided to remain devoted to this one- there was something special about it.
This is not one of your typical stories, in which two beautiful, talented beings fall in love at first sight and live happily ever after. This is a story which develops twodistinct characters, and brings them together in a very weird way. What I liked about Nodame Cantabile is that things never became very intimate. When relationships develop slowly, I feel as if they are much more precious, and that is why I enjoyed this very much. I personally loved Nodame's character development the most. One might think of her as immature and annoying at the beginning, yet her character slowly and steadily compels the audience to fall head over heels for her. She is eccentric, yet fascinating. Meanwhile, Chiaki is a very inspirational role-model. He stays faithful to his goals and remains ambitious and determined, disregarding relationships with others. 


What I also loved about Nodame Cantabile was the appreciation of music. Although I have not watched many animes yet, I was able to observe that they brought in many great musical pieces and even make me become infatuated with the orchestras. They didn't cut them, but instead took time to create tension and suspense, and show the serious and more passionate side to several characters. 


Nodame Cantabile also teaches you valuable lessons, as I suppose many great animes tend to do. It manifests the importance of working hard for the things you love, and being persistent. I liked this because it gives the whole anime value and significance, and how the characters approach their struggles made me inspired and I even began going to practice piano again for the past few weeks. 


I cannot think of something I disliked about this anime. I enjoyed it thoroughly and there never seemed to be a moment of boredom. The art seemed odd at first, but I didn't mind later after a couple of episodes because of all of the other features. I think that this is an anime for anyone whom loves music, comedy, drama, and -and of course, must have patience. If you have a heart, even a small cold one, give Nodame Cantabile a go.

I can just say that this is the best anime I have seen so far. All the elements I really love are present--comedy, romance and music. No dull moments! Every scene in this anime makes sure it would catch your attention. If you miss a scene you have to definitely track back. If you haven't seen this anime yet, I can just say you're missing half of your life! LOL. Okay, I exaggerated. Not half, maybe just a quarter of your life. Hahaha.. I got so hooked into this anime I even wrote something about it in my personal blog. You'll find the link herein my profile.\n\n
Anyway, if you already have seen it then I am certain you know what I'm talking about. ^_^

A total opposite! NODAME CANTABILE (roughly translated as THE GENTLE SONG OF NODAME) is the exact opposite of La Corda D’oro. The plot is more well-laid, the characters are realistic and most importantly the realism is totally noteworthy! I simply adore it through and through.
What triggers me to watch this anime is when I was browsing for La Carda D’oro’s review on the internet. And then, one of the reviews mentioned this anime and it is stated that the anime is good. Right after reading that, I downloaded the first 5 episodes of the anime and I have forgotten about them ever since.
Yesterday, while Iwas ‘digging into’ my lappy I just realised that there are 5 episodes of Nodame Cantabile that I have downloaded and I watched it. At first I was a tad sceptical but when I watched them (the episodes) I instantaneously addicted to this anime (what’s new?! Heheheh)!\n\n
The reason why I love this anime is because it is comical, funny and yet the theme is rather profound and endearing. There is a hint of love and romance however it is exhibited towards the end of the episodes. And the most important of all, the portrayal of the characters is also impeccable and flawless. I adore the portrayal of the protagonist, Chiaki Shinichi. He is portrayed as someone who is musically blessed, frank and rather helpful. However, he is a bit insecure about his 'weaknesses'. The other protagonist, Noda Megumi (Nodame) is the exact opposite of Chiaki however, she complements him in every single way. She is very candid, childlike and driven.\n\n
Moreover, the classical numbers used in this anime are also captivating and mesmerizing. They are Brahms', Mozart’s, Beethoven’s, Dvorák's, Rachmaninoff's, Schubert's, Liszt's and the list goes on. It’s a definitely a must-watch anime! BTW, in case you are wondering, 'cantabile' means 'a gentle and singable song'.

I recommend Nodame Cantabile to those who like comedy, classical music and have a certain degree of maturity, as this is a Seinen/Jôsei anime.
Nodame´s Cantabile main characters are Shinichi Chaiki and Noda Megumi (NodaMe:) ), two piano students with completely differents personalities and goals. Chiaki is a perfeccionist, somewhatb insensitive person, who dreams of becoming a conductor, but is afraid of traveling by plane or boat, what leaves him isolated in Japan. Nodame is a cheerful person, infantile, and with great potential, who plays music in he own way (she plays always in Cantabile, that is as if the music is a song, adding andtaking notes to what the music she is playing). Although Nodame is talented she doesn´t wants to become pro, instead she desires to become a Kindergarten Teacher.She is also Chiaki neighbor and fall in love with him. This is the basis of the story.

The real history begins after some episodes that introduce minor characters, as Mine(a violoinist), with the arrival of Franz von Stresemann, a famous conductor, who selects Chiaki as assintent conductor of Orchestra S, a recently founded Orchestra with students picked personnaly by Stresemann. Since Stresemann is a playboy who spends his time in clubs, "chasing skirts", Chiaki becomes the main conductor of Orchestra S. The next episodes are basically, Chiaki trying to control his perfeccionist nature, sometimes called Demon/Devil Chiaki, a concert performed by Orchestra S and the founding of a new orchestra which is conducted by Chiaki. At the same time, Nodame begins to understand that if she wants to be with Chaiki she must become a pro and began training to a Competition... which lead to a series of events that i can´t talk in a review since it would be spoiling too much :)


One strong point of Nodame Cantabile is the soundtrack, especially The excerpts of classical pieces of Mozart,Rachminoff,Listz,Beethoven and Brahams(Ii maybe forgotting some other compositors); the opening song and the first ending are also very good, but the second ending is weaker in my opinion; the OST is also great, contributing to the mood.


Another strong point is the artwork, on which I must say that I as surprised with the work that as been done with the finger moviments and hand positions of the characters while playing the music.


The Third strong point is the comical way in which he series is presented and the character development of Chiaki, Nodame and Stresemann.


But since perfection in this world is rare, or even non-existent, Nodame Cantabile also has some weak points. From those weak points there is oneespeccially annoying, which would be the non-development of some interesting supporting characters and plots, like the relationship between Mine and Kiyora. 


Taking everything in account, Nodame Cantabile is a anime that will certainly make you laugh with his special humour, but will also charm you with loots of really,really good classical music and a romantic history who focus in the relationships between the several characters.

Possibly the most appropriate anime for (elitist) classical music fans - if you are one of them, this anime will disappoint less than other animes involving classical music. Additionally, if you are a casual listener of music, this anime is a wonderful medium in which you can slowly develop your appreciation of classical music. 
The one thing that sets it aside from most is the effort put into animating the musicians as they are playing the music - they are very accurate in mimicking where performers' hands and fingers should be when they are performing the pieces.
The only quip that one might have is whena performance is praised, that it can be difficult to find what might be so significant about that performance that generates such a reaction from its audience. At least in the real world we have several classical musicians vying to make the concert stage, but the pure subjectivity of music means that just being able to achieve some kind of success is much more difficult than the anime suggests.\n\n
The uniqueness of the female protagonist is certainly a striking factor that gives the anime its appeal, since it represents an extreme example of one dedicated to classical music in a very different way, in contrast to a typical hardworking and committed male protagonist. Their clashing but also their interaction with each other is a central theme of the series and its sequels as they continually move forward.\n\n
To any casual viewers: this is a great way to slowly include classical music into your listening collection, as often a colouristic or historical description of the pieces are included, allowing one to really get a feel for and understand what classical music seeks to express.

Nodame Cantabile is a must watch if you love romance and comedy combine to give you yummy jam...and especially if you love classical musics.
It's a very well developed story. Each characters has a unique personality that gives the story a good boost.
Want to get inspiration in your music life? Then Nodame Cantabile is your choice. It inspired me, that's for sure. 
The musics are very good. Some are composed by famous musicians such as Mozart and Bach. The graphic is very good with a nice blend of CG and 2D animation.

Just five days ago I started to watch this anime and after finishing Nodame Cantabile Finale (the third season). I can't help feeling a little lone.
   In these five days, Nodame Cantabile made part of my life and I must say it's the first time that it happens with an anime. 
  It's almost as if I was there when Chiaki met the heroine for the first time when she was playing Beethoven's Piano Sonata No.8 or when he played Rachmaninov in the school's concert.
 I often found myself in Chiaki's apartment, where Nodame plays her passionate music whilewaiting for the dinner. And I laugh so much at her funny, weird personality that irritates our short-tempered main character.

 For the last five days, I was practicing really hard on piano, trying to get in their level and play with them.


 The key of this anime, for me, was not the music, nor the plot (though they were REALLY good). For me, the characters' personality is what makes you to enter in their world. While it alternates between the comedy of the graduate student's life and the perfectionism in the world of classical music, the anime will make you feel as if you make part of the story (or at least it feels like it to me).


 But the most difficult to accept is that it's over. I will no more travel to Momogaoka College of Music to watch Nodame and Chiaki playing Mozart together. But I know that when I calm down,  the days we spent together will always be in my memory, Nodame's music will not leave me so early.


 That is what Nodame Cantabile represents to me.

Nodame Cantabile Review (all three seasons)
overall: 7.75
Plot(8): Cantabile’s events aren’t ever too jarring or spectacular, or particularly suspenseful, but the story and sequencing of events are used well to interact with the characters. Relationships and inner worlds are developed using the plot, and vice versa, which is satisfying in the end. In addition, the plot leads the viewer on to the next episode without being overly “cliffy”. Cantabile displays a realistic portrayal of life and its happenings though the story. The plot also serves as a good framework for the overall narratives that are woven through Cantabile.
story: 7.5 interaction/support of characters: 9 narrative: 8
Characters(9): Characterdevelopment is where this series shines. There was a deeper look given to most characters, and many characters where developed even without a peek into their thoughts through the goings-on of the episodes. The struggles and solutions each character went through felt real and, as a student, very relatable. Almost nothing felt contrived or heavy-handed. Most, in a sense, felt like “real” people. Nodame in particular goes through huge changes. One very good point of the character development is that for most characters in the spotlight, the various facets of their individual persons was shown. No one is just a cheery fool all the time, though that may be what they default to most of the time. The characters and their interactions felt realistic yet still maintained a degree of originality.


development: 10 originality: 7 realistic-ness: 8.5


Execution(9): A bit of a vague category, but here I judge everything else. The sound in this musically entrenched anime was good–not once did I feel it detracted from the show. In fact, the arrangements of all the different pieces of classical music are delightful. I find myself really liking classical music now, whereas before I only tolerated the most famous pieces despite my musical inclinations. Well, that or just listening to metal versions of Mozart and the like. The voice acting is on par. Cantabile does many things well, and it all comes together in an inescapable harpoon that pierces your heart and reels you in. It is subtle, yet incredibly enchanting. All in all, Cantabile does “live up to its potential” almost always, even if it’s in ways the viewer does not expect. I would say that while the “reluctant boy meets overexcited girl” starting point is not exactly original, it doesn’t detract from the wonderful execution of their romance. To be honest, my only qualm with Cantabile is the somewhat loose ending of the series–rushed and out of character when one considers the excellent episodes that preceded it. I’m not opposed to an ‘open’ ending, but it was almost like a preview episode…in my opinion even if one leaves the ending open, it should at least be tied up a little more with the two most important characters, both individually and together.


sound: 10 “potential”: 8.5 originality: 8


Art(4.75): To be honest, I avoid a lot of anime because of the art. I’m an artist myself, so I guess I’m just strict when it comes to animation and illustration. While I loved the series, I cannot give Cantabile a good art score. However, in light of what I just said, this speaks to the strength of the plot, characters, and execution of Cantabile. I absolutely blazed through it all despite the painful art at times. What is so painful about it? The entire first season lacks animated orchestral shots. An orchestra’s movement is part of their presentation; it actually hurts Cantabile when all we see are stills every time people are playing instruments together. They hardly animate the conductors, even. There are only shots–well coordinated shots–of piano playing, and usually just arms/body + piano, or fingers+keys. When it’s another instrument, they use mediocre CGI. Or stills. There are so many stills it feels like a slideshow at points, and gets quite tiresome. The second season is a step up only because they use CGI to animate the orchestras, but due to the CGI’s conspicuousness the viewer is left wanting still. If Cantabile was animated like Shingeki no Kyojin, it would be even better than it is now in every aspect. But it’s not. Unfortunately, the anime medium is also only used in trivial ways most of the time. Cantabile could easily have been a TV show(which I’m pretty sure it is). Overall, the art detracts from the show when music is involved. While the art is not necessarily bad, due to the musical nature of the show it ends up detracting from everything else.


support of plot: 5 use of medium: 5 addition to show: 4

A slice of life, romantic comedy at heart...but this series does so much more than what other series in this genre strive to be.  An immensely popular series in Japan, this music anime is a must watch for everyone, even those uninterested in this genre or musical animes.
Story:  From the start, this series sucks you in with it's simple yet deep story with intriguing characters and nice touches of comedy.  The comedic aspect of this series never seems to be forced or out of place, but complements the story and characters amazingly well.  Too many animes nowadays spoon feed you thecomedy when it's unnecessary to it's demise, but Nodame Cantabile has the right amount of comedy all at the right places.  When it's serious, you are touched emotionally and when it's funny, you are literally LOL'ing.  The story is simple...about 2 utterly opposite kinds of music students who meet eachother and how their relationship evolves.  Through the ups and downs, you are always hooked and invested emotionally in this series and are always cheering for the characters.  Sometimes simple is the best.  A whimsical, relatable series which does not disappoint at all.


Art:  To be honest, the art is nothing special...at least for the 1st season.  That's not to say it's not well drawn.  The characters are all nicely drawn and the environment while simple, gets the mood across.  By today's standards, this anime is average.  However, the emphasis they place on the accurate depictions of the musical instruments is amazing.  In the 2nd season, when they show the musicians playing their instruments, the movements that they make are life like.  The animations of the characters playing the piano are fully fledged out in most cases and it is awe inspiring to see that they put so much work into these parts.


Sound:  Amazing!  Many music anime fail to actually implement music into their anime to its full potential.  But Nodame Cantabile does...and does so beautifully.  Even if you're not a classical music fan, this anime will turn you into one.  The scenes with the music are nicely done to immerse you into the moment.  People who play instruments will particularly enjoy this and inspire you. The voice acting is top notch as well as there are some famous actors that voice the main characters.


Characters:  What differentiates a truly great anime from the average anime are the characters.  This is even more true for slice of life animes, for the characters are what drives the scenes and the whole series.  I find many animes nowadays to just be fan service and utterly lacking in character originality and development.  Not the case for Nodame Cantabile.  From the beginning you find yourself caring and wondering more and more about the 2 lead characters Chiaki and Nodame.  Both are flawed, immature, naive characters...yet there is something admirable about them that makes you care.  The development of these two are nicely paced and never seem unnatural.  Never before in a series have I found myself wanting these two to be together as a couple.  Chiaki is a strong lead character...Nodame likewise is a very interesting, strong character.  Neither is the stereotypical "damsel in distress" kind of character where one saves the other..both are solid leads coping with their own issues and trying to get through life.  The relationship between them is a give and take, with both contributing an equal amount to their development.  

Perhaps one downside are the supporting characters.  In this series, they aren't fleshed out as much as your would like them to be.  The other characters' developments and relationships don't really matter much, and while they are likable...in the end they don't really matter.  The supporting characters are exactly what they are meant to be...just support Chiaki and Nodame's story.


Overall, a great anime and a must watch for everyone.  The relationship between Chiaki and Nodame is very refreshing.  If you really hate classicial music, then perhaps some scenes might seen a little too drawn out.

Nodame cantabile is a wellspring of fun and excitement. Chiaki Shinichi plays the Tsukkomi, the straight man, keeping the story relevant and the symbol to which we can relate to. Noda Megumi plays the Boke, the fool, entertaining us from start to finish. The duo creates an almost perfect balance of dramatic exchange and comedic relief for the series. That being said, I felt that Noda Megumi was lacking as a character as well as relevance to the plot.
The plot is driven by Chiaki's desire to become an aspiring conductor. Chiaki makes for the perfect medium for the plot, as there is never a dullmoment in his life. Chiaki might be a genius, but he works twice as hard to get what he wants. While Chiaki has his fair share of successes, he also has his share of failures. I truly felt anxiety when Chiaki was faced with a challenge. And whenever Chiaki pulled through I was there rooting for him. 


Although, I enjoyed the simple premise, However, I could not find myself enjoying this series until after episode 5. It was a chore to get through the beginning, as it felt like each episode was simply throwing a Boke at us until one of them stuck. Nodame Cantabile's attempt at giving character development to minor characters was mostly unwarranted and misplaced.The time could've been used to build Megumi's character rather than those minor characters. Megumi's engagement with Chiaki were mostly comic relief while her relevance to the plot were essentially nil. Megumi's role could've been filled with basically any other girl that was already swooning over him. Later in the season, they introduce Megumi to a plot solving ability that is never revisited. While it does keep Megumi relevant, it is by all means cheap.


The series has some beautifully painted backgrounds. The backgrounds such as Chiaki's apartment or the piano rooms being revisited gives the impression of being there. At a glance, Ninomiya/Shimamura's character designs look simple. However, the casual clothes they wore reflected their personality and vice-versa. The animation on the other hand lacks vibrance. The energy from the events stem mostly from the character themselves and the actions they take. 3D instruments make up for time but are truly noticeable contrasted by the water colored  character and backgrounds. 


Tomokazu Seki truly encompasses the character of Chiaki. His energetic outbursts to the ridiculous characters make him just as funny, if not funnier, than his comedic counterparts. His nonchalant speech displays how charming he his. Even more so when he speaks with melancholy and frustration. I never thought I could hear Ayako kawasumi sound so outrageous. If Noda Megumi's speech wasn't already crazy enough, for fans of Fate/Stay Night like me, to hear Saber scream out phrases like "Gyabon" or "Bukya" is drop dead hilarious. 


I had a lot of fun watching Nodame Cantabile. Once I got passed the first 5 episodes, I couldn't find a good spot to stop watching. To me it spells that the story progresses at a reasonable pace. At the time of writing this review, I've finished watching all 3 seasons. I truly feel that the first season was the weakest of the 3. I highly recommend people to watch through Nodame Cantabile because I believe that the true story begins in Paris.

História:
Nodame Cantabile passa-se numa Universidade/Academia de música clássica no Japão. A personagem principal é Noda Megumi, uma pianista no 1º ano da academia. A outra personagem principal é um violinista, Chiaki, Shinichi. Este anime conta a história de várias personagens, de várias orquestras, com muita comédia e romance. O desenrolar da história é algo sempre bastante imprevisível e que acaba de uma maneira fenomenal.
Classificação: 9/10
Animação:
A arte em Nodame, consegue ser bastante simplista mas com detalhes espectaculares. Quando em concerto, os grandes planos aos instrumentos em 3D enriquece bastante o anime. Não é uma arte que uma pessoa fica boquiaberta, mas é bastante agradável.
Classificação: 8/10
Música eSom:


Sendo um anime sobre música clássica é para além da comédia o ponto forte. Para além de um Opening e Ending excelentes, fez-me “crescer” e ver com outros olhos a música clássica. Durante toda a série podemos ouvir grandes compositores como Beethoven, Mozart, Bach, Debussy, etc. A música ambiente de toda a série também é muito boa.


Classificação: 10/10


Personagens:


Com um grande leque de personagens, temos claramente o destaque de Nodame. Uma desastrada pianista que não segue partituras mas consegue uma quase perfeita classificação num dos mais prestigiados concursos de música clássica Japonesa. Para além do seu grande talento musical, tenho obviamente que destacar a comédia provocada por esta em toda a série.

Temos também Chiaki-kun, um grande violinista, e com o seu talento escondido de maestro, tem medo de voar de avião e com a ajuda de Nodame perde esse medo.

Depois temos grandes personagens que dão ainda mais alegria à serie como o Mine, Masumi e o seu bigode, Kiyora, Franz von Stresemann ou também chamado Milky, entre muitos outros grandes personagens.


Classificacão: 10/10


Geral:


No geral, Nodame Cantabile é um must-see, com divertimento garantido e aumentando e muito a cultura musical de qualquer um, é um dos grandes animes e o seu rating é bem merecido. Totalmente recomendado a todos. Foi a primeira review que fiz, espero que tenham gostado.



Enjoy Rating: 10/10

Total: 9,5/10

It's a masterpiece of romance and comedy. One of its remarkable thing is how energetic Nodame would say gyabo and mukya. The story is simple yet heart warming. It is a refreshing and unique style of romance because it has no formalities. Noda Megumi and Chiaki Shinichi did not put labels to their relationship, they just go with the flow of romance but it shows through the story. The way it is narrate is very different from what I watch from other romance anime, it came from the perspective of a guy since most of romance narration begun in a heroine. Even if you don'thave a background in classical music the anime explains it simple and you will not be bored. The characters are lovable and introduced well, even the extras. Noda Megumi is one of the unpredictable characters I've watched. I like the naive, cheerful and outgoing character of Nodame. The art of characters and scenery is classic and simple, but the anime did it best to make a 3D for playing the piano and conducting. The seiyuu did a quality voice acting, they did a good work to give life to the characters, especially to the gyabo and mukya of Nodame. The opening and closing song is also good. This anime comes from Studio J.C. Staff and with director Kenichi Kasai. Both were involved with the successful slice of life anime Honey and Clover. In terms from a general perspective, both of those anime share similarities. However, it is in fact how great and developed the characters are which makes the difference in an anime like this from being great such as Honey and Clover or terrible like Nanaka 6/17 (2003).
Nodame Cantabile is a story about two piano students. One is the immensely talented Chiaki Shinichi who is seemingly great at everything music from violin to piano to even conducting. The other is thebubbly free spirit in Noda Megumi with the nickname Nodame. She is the crux of the show while the story does follow Chiaki and his journey towards becoming a great conductor while in college, competitions, and putting together fantastic performances. After a few instances occur at the start, Chiaki is somehow always drawn to Nodame. She on the other hand immediately falls in love with him. Thus, with two polar opposite personalities, creates very good comedy from start to finish.


It is not just Chiaki and Nodame as characters that mold the show. Even the vast amount of side characters come together very well. They all have incredible chemistry with each other and the story somehow incorporates the development of each characters goals throughout. However, as with a large cast, there were numerous and almost too many characters that would either contribute nothing, or have such a bit role they quickly come and go and float away. It was fairly often a character would come, get a bit of backstory and perspective from their view and then never seen again after that episode. 


Nodame as a character is fantastic and has all the proper development in the world. Her struggle to find why she enjoys the piano to overcoming past demons is why she is the shows best character and the viewer just cannot help but root for her and her happiness. Chiaki on the other hand suffers from typical male anime personality. He is perfect in almost every way from his enormous family given talent to even being rich. His one character flaw is even solved way too conveniently for the sake of the story.


Comedy hits very well and even better than in Honey and Clover because this show never tries to be totally serious. Naturally the music is littered with fantastic classical pieces, but the CG is all over the place and utterly jarring at times. Nodame Cantabile is a fantastic music anime with everything there for an enjoyable experience.

Nodame Cantabile is about a boy cat and a girl cat who attend a musical conservatoire. The boy cat, Chiaki, is a strict and  excellent piano & violin player, as well as the son of a famous musician in Japan. The girl cat, Nodame is a fun & goofy piano player who jokes around all the time but has a very genuine heart and love for piano— just as Chiaki does. 
If you asked me to give you a reason why I love Nodame Cantibile I wouldn't be able to give you just one. The story was relaxing and playful, but it could alsobe serious at times. & when it would get serious... Boy would it hit deep. There is a lot of comedy and there are a lot of different types of characters who keep the show interesting. The comedy isn't so much so that it undermines some of the more serious moments though, as I've seen that happen in other anime before. 


Nodame Cantibile will take you on a ride and you'll follow Chiaki and Nodame as they have to overcome obstacles and face new challenges and get over their fears. Whether it's sacrificing something for someone you love or taking the leap of faith and not looking back.. The characters go through a lot and you get to follow along on their journey of self discovery. Great music and musical performances accompanied by colorful harmonies of flowers and energy that was just amazing fun to watch and listen to.


A must watch for lovers of romance, music, and goofy comedy— but it is a show that will have it's moments & will tug at your heartstrings... I hope you can give it a shot.

This is about the story of a person who knows absolutely nothing about classical music (and who constantly listens to electronic music) and his journey with this magical series known as Nodame Cantabile.
***************** Overall ********************
It has been a good 9 years since the production of this anime, it is a long time indeed, but there is just something about this anime that I cannot fully explain, in a good way. Normally, classical music only appear in anime series when the MC enters the house of his rich friend, or when characters with high social status appear. In other words, classical music becomes the thing thatcreates a distance between the viewer and these characters (or surroundings). Words like extravagant, over-the-top, infinite wealth often hover around this genre of music in terms of its usage. However, with this series, these pieces, one after another, is used to communicate with the viewers. These characters are not your prince and princesses, they resonate somewhere within you. Often, they fill your heart with warmth. Classical music, it has seem, became more like a window through which we can escape into our imaginations and feelings. The previous notions I had about them being cold, and perhaps superficial, has faded away.


So then why should you give up some of your time for these 24 episodes? 


It is quite simple, really. It has been quite some time since I last find myself immersed in a series that is neither overly rushed, nor overly boring due to its length. In fact, it almost appears as if these 24 episodes have the effect of 50 episodes in some other series. Less action and round-the-bush drama, and more subtlety and good story telling. This subtlety is in terms of character growth, character development and the conveying of the message behind this series. If you want to peacefully enjoy a series that will still somehow manage to send chills down your spine and warm your heart, this is honestly quite the perfect series for you.


Moreover, this series delivered something rarely ever delivered by other series: actually impacting the viewers with music, and music alone. No need to fear, there is no 30 minutes concerts in here, but just a couple of minutes every once in  a while. These couple of minutes, however, is enough to make you appreciate classical music so much more, and for you to immerse yourself in some epic pieces that has lived on for decades, if not centuries.


Furthermore, behind these pieces, the series carry a few messages that I find quite inspirational.


***************** Life Lessons?? *******************


First of: just be you. In this series, we are introduced to many different and unique characters. They may be (very) weird, but somehow, you can still relate to them. The message here is: you really don't have to be the best at everything to be the best of yourself. As much as Chiaki is very much successful thanks to his (super duper) high ability in playing the piano, violin and also conducting, I dare argue that Megumi, in her own way, is just as impressive a character. And even though she is really bad at being neat, or at cooking, she manages to find happiness is what she does and what she likes: playing the piano. Chiaki, on the other hand, only manages to realize this thanks to Stresemann (when he told Chiaki to just enjoy playing music during performances instead of worrying too much).


However, this is where character development really kicks in. Throughout the series, Megumi slowly comes to terms with her ability. It is a process of recognition. Since the beginning, she already knew that she learns particularly fast by ears, but has yet to recognize her incredible skills. By the end of the series, she agrees to try her best to enter a school in Paris. However, unlike Chiaki, I feel that Megumi does not aim or ultimately want to be the best in the world. Instead, she came to terms with her skills and has accepted that she is a very gifted pianist (thanks to both her talent and hard work). Hence, her agreement to want to study abroad is more about wanting to discover how far her skills and hard work can take her, and not about chasing a dream. Of course, it is also because Chiaki is going to Europe as well. But unlike Chiaki, even if she is not chasing the sun, she is just as strong and impressive. The moral of the story? If you fear being too unrealistic (or being let down by your hopes) to want to be the best, try believing in your own ability and work up from there. At least, that is what I took away from this series. 


************** Romance *******************


As far as relationships in this series go, it takes quite the unique direction. What can I say...this series is a lot more real. Say bye bye to the cliches of your ordinary series, and hello to more.....ordinary relationship developments?! This series feature a very unlikely couple (to quote Misty Chronexia) but progresses their chemistry and closeness really smoothly. This series allows us to see how, slowly but surely, their fate, lives and future becomes intertwined with one another. It is like seeing a pair of dancers slowly becoming one. I am not really good with words, but I will say this much: it is awesome, and you will sincerely want to support them :)


************** Some last comments ***************


This series feature quite the daily-life-type plot. However, the characters and music of this series is what makes it so special, as if telling us that there is always a way to make out everyday lives special and interesting as well. Its art is really good in my opinion for a series that is about to celebrate its first decade. It really is not disappointing at all. Sound? Well, do I really have to answer this?! Very good, of course. This combination gives rise to a very enjoyable series which I highly recommend if you want a peaceful (yet not slow or boring) and solid series.


PS: I am giving classical music a try and am listening to Brahms as I write this. I am honestly surprised that I would one day enlighten my ears with this genre, considering that I listened to electronic music usually. It just speaks to how impressive this series is!

"The indications of the maestro, should be subtle and at the same time great." - Chiaki 
Nodame Cantabile can be summed up in the above phrase: simple and great. In addition to a romantic comedy, it's a story about music and people. It´s how wonderful this art can act in someone's life. This is what the work is all about. A good story with good characters wrapped in classical music. Soundtracks go without saying. Do I need to quote the geniuses of Beethoven, Mozart, Bach, Chopin and other masters of music? Another point that deserves attention is the realism of the anime regarding the lifeof a musician. The difficulties, the study, the dream of a career. All very well addressed during the course of the story. Even cartoon comedy works well here. The discipline of Chiaki and the spontaneity of Nodame bring a good dynamic in scene, the relationship being a fundamental and very fun point in the plot.\n
My only caveat is about economic animation. I understand for the sake of cost, letting the music play while the transition of images occurs is acceptable, but I really wish I had seen more of the instruments played on the scene. However, this does not detract from the brilliance and merit of the work. Nodame Cantabile is like classical music: simple and great.
