First impression of the anime is an arrogant character with a monkey tailing him confessing her love all over but as you get past that the beautiful music comes to light with a nice story and outshines all the annoyance. 
The story is well made although in some ways it might feel like you have to go over the first wall and go through some episodes before you get the real feel for it. At least that was how i felt as i watched it. It has a good pace and doesn't try to drag something too long but at the same time it doesn'ttry to rush things that shouldn't be rushed. Combined with the rich musical story that comes through as you hear about different pieces it makes you enjoy it even more. The story makes you want to know how far everything can get and makes you want to listen to the next piece of music that comes with it. 


In this anime its not strange that the sound or music is what brings it up to the greatest height. Not only do we here one or two instruments but we here an entire orchestra filled great music from all kinds of composers. As i said earlier the story you get from some of the pieces adds to this and makes it even more enjoyable to listen to. And the music isn't always one or the other. Its an variation of all kinds from the most enjoyable to the saddest ones. 


So to our main actors in this anime and First is Noda Megumi. At first some might be annoyed and think what am i even seeing but its her musical abilities and her sometimes interesting personality that makes it fun watching her as she aims around hoping to find out what she wants with her studies. 

2nd is our male main character chiaki shinshi who at first sounds like a snob who things most people around him is either mediocre or just suck in general. Although in his case he got the talent and effort to back his words up although hes a weird character at times. 

The combination of the two main characters is sometimes weird so if someone asks me what is even happening between those two then i frankly cant say one or the other. Although thats the first impression it gets better as both characters shows how they rely on the other although they might not do so on consciously. There is a hidden beauty in that relaitonship that is sometimes rare to find although somtimes it gets too much and i found myself irritated mostly at Noda or nodame but also at chiaki. 


So for me this is a very classical anime in every sence of the word. Its not without flaws but the music and the well done serious and good sides keeps coming up whenever you feel you want to despair over the idiocy that this anime shows at times. I loved the music story , i loved the music so that made up for an anime that at times i was afraid was becoming a manzai ( comedy duo). 


Overall i thought it was a very good anime but with flaws that crept up. Not only small flaws but flaws that almost made me want to not watch it. Example being as said earlier the stupidity of the main characters and sometimes feeling like i watch a circus performance for than a music anime intended to show classical music. Those reasons are why i gave it a 8. It leans on a 9er but its far away from in my opinion to be called a masterpiece. If your looking for an anime that has classical music in its almost purest form i highly recommend this anime although with its flaws its still an anime i would recommend to anyone with an interest in classical music. Just be ready that there will be times were you think if it gets too much then just remember the music that comes and it will be fine.

First of all, I never write reviews. I read them religiously though so that I can avoid animes that are a waste of time. Today I am writing because I am so upset with the high ratings of this anime.
This may be biased, but honestly, I was on a romance spree and I happened to find this anime in that "category". After reading reviews - I decided to give it a try (though I did not like the art style right off the bat).
I adored "Your lie in April" though I am not a huge fan of musical animes, I bawled my eyes out forthat one.  It opened my horizons to the possibilities of music based anime. 


Sadly, this anime ruined it for me.


If I wanted to watch an Orchestra online, I would go and do so. This was listening to classical music and seemingly recycled freeze frames of them playing over it. Boring! But I wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt so I watched it until the end. I WANTED ROMANCE, DAMN IT. And it gave me a LITTLE something in the last episode but BARELY.  The music was beautiful, though classical is not my music taste, I can still appreciate it.  I just wish they added more story and less scenes of them "playing". 


I wouldn't recommend this anime to anyone who is looking for a romance fix, it wasn't funny and it really just drowned on. If you are someone looking for a good romantic anime - Lovely Complex had me squealing~  (though that anime also had its downfalls, it was hilarious and made my heart race and... they kiss, it was majestic). 


Nodame Cantabile was far from exciting and I wish I didn't watch it as it was 20 something episodes. Life = wasted.


But at least it's still not as bad as Chobits.

Nodame Cantabile review (mild spoilers)
The Plot:
The plot is very weak because it's like picking up a comic where Batman is fighting the Joker and that's it,  we know that Batman wants to stop the Joker and put him in Arkham but we don't know the full story and it's a little weak on it's own. 
What I Like:
-The Animation, the animation is very good, I don't what to say other than "I like it"
-The Use of Classical, sounds weird I know but hear me out, instead of making their own fully original soundtrack, they used classical music for setting the tone, wether for comedyor drama they use classical music which is good in an anime about classical music. \n
-How it Revolves Around an Orchestra, it revolves around a whole orchestra and classical music as a whole not just one or two instruments.\n
-Two Characters, I only really like Chiaki and Mine. Chiaki grew from someone who was really unlikable for the first 6 episodes to someone I actually like but when he slips up, while realistic, makes him slightly less likable and Mine was enjoyable since the 3rd episode.\n
-The Sound, the whole sound design in general is very good.\n
What I Don't Like:\n
-The Stills, the animation is good but underused, in the orchestra performances they use stills, it gets better in the later eps but I still think the amount of stills are a problem.\n
-Most Characters, besides Chiaki and Mine, all the other characters are unlikable or annoying. Nodame started to get development at ep 15 but she is ultimately still annoying.\n
-The Plot, it isn't really that interesting, it doesn't really have a reason to keep me interested other than Chiaki who took 6 episodes to become likable. Chiaki does have a goal but even then it's not enough to keep me interested.\n
-How Much I Understand, because Nodame Cantabile is about conducting, it should teach me enough so I understand what the character is doing but not so much it feels like a textbook, Nodame Cantabile does neither, I came out with the same amount of knowledge as I had going in, the worst part about it is that I learnt that there is an instrument called a Oboe that you have to make the reed for but I didn't learn anything about conducting.\n\n
It's strange, I have listed more positives than negatives but I don't like it, it's well made which is why it's a 7 but I just don't like it personally.\n
I would say there's nothing interesting but I stayed till the end so I like to think of it like a snack: there isn't anything to fill you up or make you feel satisfied but it sustains you until dinner.\n

How to describe the first season of this series?
Well, if we go ahead and check my overall result, then it is a Good show.
Now, normally, when pointed to make a review, anybody's initiative is to give the "essence" of the product. Somehow, trying to amuse the reader, without giving a full taste of it, or finding a strongly resourceful way to prove it is actually awful and, of course, during the whole experience, the reviewer didn't connect positively, so the same will happen to you. Still, the chance gets to anybody. Being said, there are reasons to love, like, or just show straight hate regardingthis.\n
Do you know the formula of most sports anime? Create interaction between characters, exhibiting how good the sport actually is by making it look complex through a series of challenges presented as if anybody in the game had superpowers, progressing and evolving alongside the story. Nodame (Anime) is similar, believe it or not, but has a more realistic vibe to it. No, there is no such thing as crazy artwork to support a confront - there are none. What does exist are musical performances, and the music really does the trick. What about the complex exploration of music? Well, the first step to understand that is the location of the action. The characters play music as students in a University. Also, they have been studying music for a few years there. So, not only do you follow mature people (not that much, unfuckingfortunately), they aren't playing just for fun. It is not a "Sorry, I played the wrong note. Hahaha." case. Here, things are serious (not that much - anime has had its horrible clichés for a long extension, now). This complex state is developed, thanks to these components, by different pieces, the search of perfection, musical theory and the moving road of life (you need to remember: it is also a romance story). In the end, music is the cause, the dilemma, yet the fascinating thing that will make you want to get closer to its foundations.\n
The other good side is the comedy (more mature - still a somewhat childish, though), the drama between characters and their inner-self, as well as the fresh way time, places, situations are explored, something a bit uncommon in this industry's achievements - here, a procedure more honest (sometimes). But this may also be a bad news - every time a new take is done regarding anything, there are always mixed emotions.\n
The sound is another part to be careful about. Most of what you will hear are shortened versions of classical and neoclassical music. Orchestra and piano may not be your thing...\n
Last thing to report, well... is the story. During the streaming time you probably won't have a problem with it. But, once finished, you will look back and say to yourself "Anime...".\n
Concluding, Nodame Cantabile isn't about what you accomplish. It is about the unknown paths you take in life.\n

The first few episodes of this anime deserve a 10/10. They are hilarious, heartfelt, and compelling. The characters are fantastic, have great chemistry, and feel realistic - even though they can be over-the-top at times. There is representation of multiple sexualities, and even a trans (ish? maybe?) character.
Then Stresemann is introduced. Boob-grabbing, womanizing Stresemann. The plot and character chemistry all go down from there, unfortunately. The anime became more plot-based, rather than character based, from there on out. So it wasn't very satisfying for me.
I loved the realistic art style of the characters (if I had started up just one more anime to find itoverloaded with moe, I swear to god). Unfortunately, however, the orchestral scenes themselves were very flat. They were often just still frames and weird pans of abstract art. You can see the budget.


But those first few episodes. They redeem everything.

Its been an awful long time since I first watched this anime, and recently i re-watched it to see if it still gave me that chill of excitement everyone a musical number was played, And it did.
This review is some what biased purely for the reason that I am a lover of classical music anyway, but that does not mean any old anime that has a few piano numbers is enough to swoon me, no, it has to have more, and nodame cantobile, had all that I needed.
Like all my reviews I'm not going to explain the story, their is a synopsis at the topso read that, this is just my personal opinion of the anime.\n
There is no one great thing about this anime, there are various great things, the one that stuck out to me the most that i noticed when rachmianov concerto no 2 was being played, is that the animators manage to capture every note as it was being played, what I mean to say is that it was not just repeated animation the characters were doing when a song was being played, they were playing the actual notes as they should be, that, in itself, amazed me.\n\n
Then again, you may not like classical music, if so, i still strongly urge you to watch this, the comedy value alone is enough to have you literally on the floor in stitches, the two main characters are by far the most creative piece of animated work I have seen in a very long time, Kudos also to the voice actors themselves.\n\n
In conclusion, if you love comedy, and happen to love music, you would be absolutely daft, not to watch this.

I just finished this anime and I felt a real pressing need to review it right away. It's about an arrogant but truly talented pianist and violinist named Chiaki whom, due to childhood circumstances, is unable to travel abroad to pursue his music. He remains in grad school in the hopes of one day being able to be a conductor for an orchestra. He meets an unruly but gifted pianist named Noda Megumi (Nodame for short) who happens to be his next door neighbour and a student in the same university. This hilarious and breathtaking anime goes into the story of their relationship and thedevelopment of their talents as musicians, as well as the friends and colleagues they meet along the way. 


Story: 10/10

This is my first music-centered anime and I must say it was captivating. It shows the hard work, perseverance, discipline and passion of musicians in a very realistic but also humorous way. Not once did I ever find myself dosing off or distracted. The storytelling was effective without being flashy or unrealistic, which I really appreciated. It did not need a heavy amount of drama or comedy elements to make it captivating. I also really appreciated the ending, as everything tied together very nicely. If this was a single season only I still would have rated it highly but because there are more seasons, I believe it deserves a perfect score. I am looking forward to SO MUCH MORE. If you enjoy stories such as Skip Beat, where a character is underestimated but has immense hidden talent, you will thoroughly enjoy watching Nodame. 


Art: 9/10

The art to me was adequate in most areas but what made me give it a 9/10 was the animation/drawing of the instruments. When the instruments were being played (particularly the violin and the oboe) they looked so real I felt as if I could reach into the screen and touch them. This made the performance scenes that much more enjoyable to watch. 


Sound: 11/10

If it was possible to score as such I would. The music in this anime is absolutely breathtaking. There were multiple moments of awe and teary eyes watching and listening to the characters perform. I expected a lot from a music anime but it went above and beyond my expectations....It really made classical music seem romantic and exciting but also cool and kind of hipster too :P. It seriously increased my appreciation for the arts. Ohhh and the opening theme is very catchy as well :)


Character: 10/10

The main characters of Nodame and Chiaki were developed just the right amount for the story they were telling. I loved both of their personalities, especially in combination as they make a great duo. What I really appreciated was the development of many supporting characters. They might not have spent a lot of time with them but at the end as a viewer, I believed and shared each of their passions for their craft after seeing their characters unfold. I also really appreciated the different personalities of the characters. The main and supporting characters all had something that made them unique, which also helped me appreciate their musical performances. What I appreciated the most was the emphasis that as talented as any of these individuals seemed, it came with hard work, even with Nodame (as gifted as she is). 


Enjoyment: 10/10

Overall: 10/10 

There is not much more I can say about this anime without being repetitive. It was a joy to watch; really amplifying my love for music but also really making me care about the characters. I am looking forward to watching the next 2 seasons and reviewing those as well. This is definitely a unique anime worth watching and I believe it has a little something for everyone.

If you've ever played a musical instrument you'll love this anime.
Nodame Cantabile has so many things going for it, even with a story you've heard many times before. 
Main protagonist Chiaki has always dreamed of becoming a conductor and studying under his idol Viera. After a terrifying plane ride to his mother in Japan, Chiaki is left with an overwhelming phobia of flying. This leaves him unable to fully realize his dream of studying with Viera—or even to simply study abroad. Resigning himself to the fact that he's stuck in Japan, he studies different instruments in effort to understand them better while still secretly yearningto be a conductor. 


After growing somewhat bitter, and with a bit of a superiority complex, Chiaki overhears a wonderful piano melody that captivates his attention. Later Chiaki discovers that the person responsible for the melody is none other than his scatterbrained next-door neighbor Nodame. Nodame is every bit Chiaki's opposite, free-spirited, unrestrained, outgoing, and also unbelievably messy. No... not just messy... horrendously FILTHY. 


Chiaki gets roped into cleaning her apartment, cooking meals for her, and coaching her at piano—subsequently developing a reluctant affection for her that he denies at every opportunity. There are also a plentiful amount of other colorful characters in this series. Mine the violinist, Masumi the timpanist, and of course perverted conductor Stresseman, to name just a few.


The art style is pleasant, nothing too over-the-top spectacular. However, the animation for the character's hands and movements while playing each individual instrument is given special attention, and it really shows. Additionally, the humorous moments are given very cute flourishes that are reminiscent of the manga.


Sound. This is where the anime really shines. Not only do they pick some of the best classical compositions, they also elaborate on why each one is notable. They give each piece detail and perspective. I love the two different ways Mine and Chiaki view "Spring". I love how much time is put in to tell you about each piece of music. The sounds of each instrument are wonderful, the accuracy of each instrument when it's out of tune, as well as how differently Chiaki and Nodame play a piece on piano. I could go on forever, there's just so much RIGHT with how this series does sound. 


Characters. Again, each individual character is likable with their own distinct personality. They're memorable, they're enjoyable, and all of them assist the main protagonist's growth throughout the series. You're able to really remember each character with vivid clarity. 


Enjoyment? Supremely enjoyable. It has a very refreshing balance to the overall story, and there's not a single dull moment. You never find yourself bored, or getting 5 episodes in and then forgetting about it. You can watch it from start to finish with ease, and even find yourself wanting to go back and re-watch it. 


My only nitpick with the series, which is very common in anime, is that everyone is in love with the main character Chiaki. I mean, they think this guy is a musical god. They either love and idolize him, or they hate him based upon jealousy and envy. It doesn't really seem necessary, and doesn't add to the story in the slightest. But honestly that's just nitpicking at this point.


Give it a watch, you'll be glad you did!

Alright this is my first review but I felt obligated to do it because I am an aspiring classical musician and this show is all about classical music.
Anyways down to business. There are plenty of good reviews of this anime so I'll keep this fairly short and stick to what I know. First off I want to say I was very skeptical about watching this show. Usually anything that deals with classical music for the masses is done poorly and they often use extremely popular and over played pieces. I'm very happy to say this is not the case in Nodame Cantabile. I was continuouslypleased and surprised right up until the very end at the diversity of the pieces they chose. I was possibly even more excited at the recordings used for all the playing. Although not easily noticeable, when the orchestra/person paying was supposed to be making mistakes I could tell that there were mistakes, even if it wasn't exactly the mistakes they were supposed to be. Also whenever they had a big performance of a piece the recording used is always very good quality. I should mention though that they never play a piece all the way through. However seeing as many classical pieces are 10+min long, symphonies being 30+min, it just wouldn't have been practical to try and fit entire pieces in, there wouldn't have been any story. As far as animation is concerned they use a lot of still pictures for performances and such. They did animate the playing sometimes, especially near the end, but it was mostly still shots. Although this may seem like a bit of a let down it was certainly easier than trying to animate all of the musicians movements. I feel that if they would have done this it would wind up taking away from the accuracy of this show which is pretty much spot on. I was very happy about how they managed to capture what it's like to really be an aspiring classical musician. I don't think there was ever a time in the show that I found myself thinking something like "that's not what happens in the real world". The show did have it's fair share of prodigies but it was still well within the realm of believability. In the end I started this anime expecting to hate it and I wound up loving it. For anyone who is a classical musician or really likes classical music you need to watch this now. Even if you're not a big classical music buff though there is still plenty to be enjoyed and I highly recommend it.

It’s very rare for musical type of series to be famous considering that not everyone is fond of music. So it’s to be expected that there would be a very few viewers who will genuinely appreciate such genre. I strongly believe that it would be an extreme challenge to create such one.
There’s a long review coming!
ABOUT THE STORY
The series is about different people with different ambitions and the only thing that everyone has is music. The story revolves around students in a music university and how they struggle to achieve their dreams in the music industry.
Like I said, I believe that with the type ofgenre it would definitely be a challenge as so viewers can really appreciate the series. In this case, the production manages to create such series which not only Japanese viewers can appreciate but in overseas, too. Which I think is such a success. I believe it’s very refreshing considering I am personally not quite excited at the beginning because though I am in love with music, musical type of series is not really my cup of tea. Before I realized it, I was already amazed with almost every episode. The fact that it’s not only about music but also about people’s lives, decisions, dreams, and problems are what makes the series even more amazing. Plus, the whole series is packed with lots of laughter so you will really enjoy every moment of it. Oh, and there is also romance though I think the series is more about the people’s lives rather than the love story of the main characters. I am not that knowledgeable with classical music, though I have few personal favorites, I strongly believe that it made the series with a refreshing and different touch from others. I absolutely think that music or soundtracks are very important to any type of stories. Be it movies or series, music can always give a huge impact to the flow of story and delivers it to any type of viewers. \n\n
ABOUT THE CHARACTERS\n
Though the two lead characters are both musically talented, they approach music in a very different way. Chiaki is the type who’s genuinely talented that everyone knows. He considers music in a serious way and dreams of becoming someone in the music industry someday much like your typical person with a talent. On the other hand, Nodame is the type who approaches music in her own way where she considers it a fun thing and unlike Chiaki she never considered becoming a professional someday. This is something that in fact common in real life where people expect you to become someone because of your talent and consider it a waste of talent if you’re not planning on becoming professional. Now, this is where the conflict comes between them and Nodame have to decide whether to treat music straight on or else she can’t be with Chiaki. I honestly think that Nodame is way better than Chiaki and they should just leave her alone. It’s really irritating when a person pushes their beliefs with you and I even consider it an insult if they would say that it’s a waste of talent. At the end of the day, if you’re not really enjoying what you are doing then it’s absolutely wrong. In life, more than fame, more than dreams, more than everything else, it is still way more important that you love what you are doing.\n\n
ABOUT THE ANIMATION and SOUND\n
Animation was not that fabulous but it worked for the type of story. Let’s not forget that the music was beautifully done. Even the voice of Nodame was so perfect for her character with all the Mukyas and Gyabos. \n\n
I enjoyed it more than I expected. Definitely looking forward to the Paris Chapter.\n

This show has so many ups and downs for me that's it's hard to write about without sounding overly praising or overly damning. The basic premise isn't particularly mind-blowing, but the execution is so solid that I couldn't help but fall in love with the series and it's quirky characters.
The anime has two basic plots: the romance plot between the two main characters and then a subplot about the philosophy of music, how the music industry works, and how musicians see their art. The subplot isn't as high brow as I'm making it sound, but it is sufficiently deep to provoke thought about deeper subjectseven if the series itself isn't bold enough to dive quite that deep.


The main appeal of this series for me is the music. As a musician who has played the trumpet and piano for the past 20 years, the story and characters really resonated with what I've experienced in my life. The pieces of music presented in the series are some of the most well known and oft-played pieces by aspiring musicians (and orchestras). They are competently played and wonderful to listen to. The link between the music and plot is usually significant and adds weight to the performances that appear in most episodes. Characters playing music takes up a significant percentage of any particular episode's screen time, so if you totally off-put by classical music this would be a series to pass on.


Rather than write separate reviews for the other series, I'd just like to elaborate on the the Paris and Finale sequels that follow, so someone who wants to watch the show to completion will know what to expect. I felt like the plot got more full of filler as the series went on, which is why I only gave the show an 8/10. If the show had been 24-26 episodes (in total including the sequels) and resolved the plot in that time, I probably would've enjoyed it more, but it drags its feet too much in the middle for my taste and does the time-honored anime trope of causing silly misunderstandings between the romantic characters that then gets resolved an episode or two later. If three or four of those plot elements had been removed the series would've been 10 episodes shorter and much less annoying in the middle. Many of these "misunderstandings" seem to have been built to show how insecure Nodame was, but I think the point was sufficiently clear after the first 1 or 2.


Overall, I still thoroughly enjoyed the show and would recommend it to fans of romance, comedy, and/or music.

I am biased in this anime as a classical pianist myself, but otherwise...

Sometimes you see a series you can't help yourself but write a review as it stands out from the rest and Nodame Cantabile is one of those.
Nodame Cantabile is about Shiniji Chiaki an arrogant music student at Japan's best music school and is from an eminent musical family is a perfectionist who demands high standards from others as well as himself with ambitions to be a conductor. He is heading for a bright feature in classical music and has a wealthy and suitable girlfriend.
This all changes after an argument with his teacher and he is relegated to the lower class of his year and isdumped by his girlfriend. Leaving the music school is hears an extraordinary yet undisciplined performance on the piano and it turns out it is Megumi Noda who prefers to be called Nodame. She is an messy girl who lives next door to Chiaki and decides that Chiaki is her boyfriend. Chiaki's life is turned upside down as he takes it upon himself to get Nodame disciplined enough to fulfill her potential.


My friend's wife went to a top music school and after going to some of their parties I found that people like how Chiaki was in the beginning do exist at music schools. Arrogant enough to be convinced of their brilliance and eager to criticise others flaws.


In many ways Nodame Cantibile is like a high school romance like Toradora or even Kimi ni Todoke with two people meeting with one looking after the other and growing as people whilst receiving advice from an irresponsible adult. In this case the irresponsible adult is Milch Stresemann an genius conductor yet an outrageous pervert who has come to Japan to find the love of his youth.


Chiaki's problems turn out to be a blessing in disguise as he learns from his other students in the lower class how to enjoy the music and not take it too seriously and from Stresemann that to be a conductor you have to show humility and appreciate the orchestra's work and limits. With Nodame's support he is able to overcome his family problems and fear of flying to progress his career abroad. If only he could appreciate Nodame. Nodame on the other hand learns that to succeed in life you have to be disciplined and at some point what you really want from life.


The secondary characters complement Chiaki and Nodame really well and the series allow these characters to develop as people as well even throwing in another chalk and cheese romance.


The music is outstanding with most of it from the Nodame Orchestra. The series also explains the music with what each piece is about and why a piece is being played so badly so you are not confused why Chiaki gets angry or what is wrong with Nodame's piano playing.


Like all the best romance anime's it is the personal growth of the characters that make the series work but as good as it is it slows a bit in the middle so it loses a mark but it is still more than enjoyable.

Nodame is one of  my favorite animes. Here's why:
Story: 10/10
Nodame Cantabile has just enough plot quirk to keep you intrigued as these characters take their emotional journeys. The story is your basic opposites attract plot for the most part. But, what is an aspiring classical conductor to do when he's afraid to fly (or sail) to Europe where destiny beckons and is instead landlocked in Japan? What do the fates have in store? This is a major point of the plot and it flows together rather well up to its resolution.
Art: 10/10
Simple character art, but not off-putting. The best part that makes this a10 for me is probably the CG usage with the instrument close-ups. Some of Chiaki's CG conducting ventured a little into uncanny valley at times, but it did not detract terribly. This overall made what could have been bland (to some) orchestral scenes "sing". 


Sound: 10/10

Well, obviously given that this is an anime about classical music students, the music is the driving force. Of course, the music was absolutely beautiful in this anime. (My personal favorite is Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No.2, but all of it was perfect). 


Character: 10/10

 In Chiaki, the aspiring conductor, you have your good looking, talented, intelligent guy that everyone (even the guys) want...but he's a perfectionist to a fault thus doesn't really relate well with others. Enter Nodame, the aspiring...kindergarten teacher...who is unkempt, chaotic and of average intelligence...but she plays amazing (albeit "sloppy") classical piano by ear/memory with all of the vim and vigor she has for life and love. The supporting characters were fleshed out and they complimented the main cast well. For example, there's a great moment during the S-Oke's first performance between Mine and Chiaki. You'll have to watch it to see. I think it'd be hard not to smile.


Enjoyment: 10/10

Your mileage may vary on this, and I think it depends heavily on your tolerance for classical music. Again, this is an anime about aspiring classical musicians, so there are many many scenes at recitals, concerts, competitions etc... The characters are well developed however and if any anime can convert a non-believer in classical music, this is the one. With just about every  piece presented, there is information and background given by Chiaki's inner voice that makes it all more understandable to the viewer. There is however, great humor and great drama between the characters. You really feel for them and want them to succeed. 


Overall: 10/10

Overnight being a surpising new addition to my "favourite anime" list, Nodame Cantabile has indeed been enjoyable. Being the first part of the threequels, it really set up the foundation. What I enjoyed most about the series, however, was the intricate use of music as the centerfold for all aspects of character and plot development, expressing the personalities and plot artifacts without ever needing to explicitly "say" anything. Rachmaninov's Piano Concerto No.2 Mvt.1 was played during the a period of plot with tension, contemplation, frustration, despair, and hope - much like the song itself.
The use of the music as both a plot enhancer and foresightfurther brought out the richness of the music, and being a musician myself, I can't help but feel the warm tingly sensation that is Nodame Cantabile.
